items.title: Big City, Crazy Killer, Loner Cop
items.abstract: In Warren Ellis’s “Gun Machine” a murderous psychopath who believes he is a resident of pre-colonial Manhattan is tracked by a messy, isolated police detective.

items.title: What Constitutes Good and Bad Web Design?
items.abstract: Well-crafted sites need to fulfill their functions efficiently and engagingly.

items.title: An Urban Standard, Coolly Reimagined
items.abstract: William Lescaze’s 1935 Kramer house, like many Modernist houses, is not weathering well.

items.title: New York City Elections Are Becoming Ever More Costly
items.abstract: The city’s Board of Elections has been consistently criticized for the manner in which it runs elections even as its budget has soared.

items.title: Country Returns to City Radio: After 17 Years, a Home in New York
items.abstract: Nash FM, at 94.7 FM, will fill a conspicuous gap in the city’s media market and serve as a flagship for a multimedia engine that will promote the “country lifestyle.”

items.title: Taliban Step Up Urban Assaults, Testing the Mettle of Afghan Forces
items.abstract: The government is trying to reassure citizens while the Taliban appears to be trying to strengthen its hand before peace talks.

items.title: Josef Frank: Celebrating the Anti-Design Designer
items.abstract: The Austrian Museum of Applied Arts/Contemporary Art has mounted the biggest exhibition of the designer's work in 30 years, hoping to burnish his reputation.
keywords: Austrian Museum of Applied Arts / Contemporary Art (Vienna, Austria)

items.title: New York City’s Pension System in Danger of ‘Operational Failure,’ Report Says
items.abstract: The bureau managing the city’s retirement funds has not kept up with the times and lacks basic tools to identify risk, according to an independent report commissioned by the city comptroller’s office.

items.title: Reps in the City That Has No Rest Days
items.abstract: A daylong stakeout at Synergy Fitness, a 24-hour gym, reveals the city’s workout rhythms.

items.title: Britain Aims to Strengthen North’s Cities
items.abstract: Under a “Northern Powerhouse” plan, the government has pledged to build more roads and railways, invest in technology and research hubs, and even appeal to China’s development bank for funds.

items.title: The Army, in Need of Recruits, Turns Focus to Liberal-Leaning Cities
items.abstract: Too few recruits are signing up from cities like Chicago and Seattle, so the Army is trying to frame enlistment as a patriotic detour.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: Of 800,000 Poor New Yorkers, Only 30,000 Can Get the New Half-Priced MetroCards
items.abstract: The city’s new Fair Fares program will get off to a modest start, with only those receiving cash assistance from the city eligible for the discounts.

items.title: How Cities Make Money by Fining the Poor
items.abstract: In many parts of America, like Corinth, Miss., judges are locking up defendants who can’t pay — sometimes for months at a time.

items.title: Tips for Traveling Cheaply in Any City
items.abstract: Staying comfortable and staying connected away from home can be expensive, but it doesn’t have to be.

items.title: Three Tap-Ins and Manchester City Is Back to Its Old Self
items.abstract: Manchester City past Arsenal, 3-1, behind three Sergio Agüero goals that were straight off Pep Guardiola’s drawing board.

items.title: How to Design a Home Gym That You’ll Actually Use
items.abstract: As the pandemic rages on, the safest place to work out is at home. Here’s how to create a personal gym you’ll want to spend time in.

items.title: New York Plans to Install ‘Vending Machines’ With Anti-Overdose Drugs
items.abstract: In addition to naloxone, a medication used to reverse opioid overdoses, the machines will distribute free syringes, toiletries and safe-sex kits.

items.title: An Alabama Town’s Sewage Woes Test Biden’s Infrastructure Ambitions
items.abstract: The new law allocates $11.7 billion for wastewater and stormwater projects. Will it get to the impoverished communities who need it most?

items.title: India’s budget focuses on roads, but critics see need for more jobs.
items.abstract: Narendra Modi’s plan calls for a big increase in infrastructure spending. Some say more must be done to create jobs for the country’s young work force.

items.title: ‘This Is Not My City’: Protesters Turn a Quiet Capital Upside Down
items.abstract: The Ottawa protesters are giddy with their sense of collective purpose. But local residents see the demonstration as an unruly, disrespectful and even dangerous occupation.
